org.gerstner.oauth2android
Class Server

java.lang.Object
  org.gerstner.oauth2android.Server

public class Server
extends java.lang.Object

The Server class contains all necessary information on the service providers urls and a few preferences regarding the behavior of the server.
All urls and other informations for this class can be found in the service providers documentation. Essential to the OAuth flow are the three urls leading to the service providers endpoints. As there are:

  • authorization endpoint - Url to the authorizationServer where the client requests authorization from the resource owner
  • token endpoint - Url to the accessTokenServer where the client presents his authorization and changes it for an access token
  • resource endpoint - Url leading to the resourceServer where the client presents his access token to gain access to the protected resources he requested
All these urls should be definite and complete but without any optional parameters for they will be included in the request in another manner.
 Example urls:

 authorization endpoint =  "https://login.example.com"
 token endpoint = "https://www.example.com/token"
 resourece endpoint = "https://www.example.com/resource"

Author:
Christoph Gerstner
See Also:
accessTokenServer, authorizationServer, resourceServer, preferredHttpMethod, useAuthorizationHeader

Field Summary
private  java.lang.String accessTokenServer
          The server issuing access tokens to the client after successfully authenticating the resource owner and obtaining authorization.
private  java.lang.String authorizationServer
          The authorization endpoint is the server, that is capable of issuing the authorization from the resource owner - it may be the same endpoint as the access token server
private  java.lang.String preferredHttpMethod
          Flag indicating the preferred Http Method (GET, POST ...) for resource operation.
private  java.lang.String resourceServer
          The server hosting the protected resources, capable of accepting access tokens and responding to protected resource requests.
private  boolean useAuthorizationHeader
          Flag to indicate if the server preferres the use of the "Authorization" Http-Header.
 
Constructor Summary
Server(java.lang.String authorizationServer, java.lang.String accessTokenServer, java.lang.String resourceServer)
          Constructs a newly allocated Server object holding all neccessary endpoint urls.

 void useAuthorizationHeader(boolean useHeader)

Field Detail

authorizationServer

private java.lang.String authorizationServer
The authorization endpoint is the server, that is capable of issuing the authorization from the resource owner - it may be the same endpoint as the access token server

See Also:
accessTokenServer, resourceServer

accessTokenServer

private java.lang.String accessTokenServer
The server issuing access tokens to the client after successfully authenticating the resource owner and obtaining authorization. May be the same endpoint as the authorization server.

See Also:
authorizationServer, resourceServer

resourceServer

private java.lang.String resourceServer
The server hosting the protected resources, capable of accepting access tokens and responding to protected resource requests.

See Also:
accessTokenServer, authorizationServer

useAuthorizationHeader

private boolean useAuthorizationHeader
Flag to indicate if the server preferres the use of the "Authorization" Http-Header. Set to true by default - since the server MUST be capable of accepting authorization through the header.

preferredHttpMethod

private java.lang.String preferredHttpMethod
Flag indicating the preferred Http Method (GET, POST ...) for resource operation. Standardized values are available in the Connection class.

useAuthorizationHeader

public void useAuthorizationHeader(boolean useHeader)
May be set to false to force the client to include the access token in the requests url or request body instead of using the http "Authorization" request header. This flag is set to true by default.

Parameters:
useHeader - true to use the authorization header, false otherwise
See Also:
useAuthorizationHeader

useAuthorizationHeader

public boolean useAuthorizationHeader()
Returns the state of the authorization header flag useAuthorizationHeader. If not changed, this flag is set to true by default.

Returns:
true if the client can use the http "Authorization" request header, false otherwise

getPreferredHttpMethod

public java.lang.String getPreferredHttpMethod()
Returns the preferred Http Method (GET, POST, ... ) for the protected resource request.

Returns:
string indicating the preferred http method
See Also:
Connection.HTTP_METHOD_DELETE, Connection.HTTP_METHOD_GET, Connection.HTTP_METHOD_POST, Connection.HTTP_METHOD_PUT
